intro: Drymonia semicordata, commonly known as the heartleaf lantana, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Verbenaceae family and is characterized by its heart-shaped leaves and clusters of small, fragrant flowers. The plant typically grows in wetland habitats, such as marshes and swamps, where it thrives in moist, nutrient-rich soils. Its flowering period occurs in late summer to early fall, producing vibrant purple or red blooms. Drymonia semicordata is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and support local wildlife.
